choices.C: In repetitive process flows with no more than 10 loops
choices.D: In repetitive processes that requires sub-playbook re-execution
choices.B: When continuously ingesting incidents from third-party systems
choices.A: In repetitive process flows to iterate for each playbook input

discussion.content: A,D is correct

Selected Answer: AD
A,D is correct

Selected Answer: AD
AD is correct

questions.question_text: In which two scenarios would it be appropriate to implement a loop for a sub-playbook? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Configurations like A, C, and D may not represent standard distributed database implementations due to their mix of components that do not align well with common practices in distributed database architecture. For instance, having two main databases might suggest replication or high availability setups, but this alone doesn't fit the typical distributed model as cleanly as option B.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
B is correct. https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XSOAR/6.6/Cortex-XSOAR-Administrator-Guide/Best-Practices

Answer is B. Not matter how many node servers you have there is always ONE app server. There only ever ONE main database server and the rest are NODE servers. 
Search for Admin Guide 6.0-1.pdf page 79

questions.question_text: Which configuration is a valid distributed database (DB) implementation?

choices.C: 2 application servers, 1 main DB, 1 node server
choices.B: 1 main DB, 1 application server, 3 node servers
choices.A: 2 main DBs, 1 application server, 2 node servers
choices.D: 1 application server, 2 main DBs, 1 node server

discussion.content: correct
